instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used in the investigation of red onion skin (OS) phenolic composition?
Output: In the investigation of red onion skin (OS) phenolic composition, two types of spectra were used: Visible Near-Short-Wave infrared (VNIR-SWIR) spectra ranging from 350-2500 nm and Fourier-Transform-Mid-Infrared (FT-MIR) spectra ranging from 4000-600 cm(-1).

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were employed in the investigation of red onion skin (OS) phenolic composition?
Output: The spectral feature processing methods employed in the investigation of red onion skin (OS) phenolic composition were multiplicative signal correction (MSC) and second order derivatization with the Savitzky–Golay method.

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the model performance in the investigation of red onion skin (OS) phenolic composition, and how accurate was it in predicting the Total Monomeric Anthocyanin Content (TAC)?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the model performance was the coefficient of determination (R-2), root mean square error (RMSE), and residual predictive interval quality (RPIQ). The model using the k-nearest neighbors algorithm with 1st derivative VNIR-SWIR spectra at 350-2500 nm had an R-2 value of 0.82, an RMSE of 0.52, and an RPIQ of 3.56 for predicting the Total Monomeric Anthocyanin Content (TAC).

instruction: Can the k-nearest neighbors model from 1st derivative VNIR-SWIR spectra at 350-2500 nm be considered superior to traditional methods in predicting the Total Monomeric Anthocyanin Content (TAC) of red onion skin (OS)?
Output: Yes, the k-nearest neighbors model from 1st derivative VNIR-SWIR spectra at 350-2500 nm can be considered superior to traditional methods in predicting the Total Monomeric Anthocyanin Content (TAC) of red onion skin (OS). The model achieved a high R-squared value of 0.82, indicating a strong correlation between the predicted and reference values of TAC. Additionally, the root mean square error (RMSE) value of 0.52 and the relative performance index for quantification (RPIQ) value of 3.56 further support the accuracy and reliability of the model in predicting TAC.
